security_audit.summary: Memory management system with minimal risk. Contains Python and bash scripts for querying markdown files within its own directory. Uses standard system utilities (find, grep, date) for file operations. No network access, no credential handling, no external data exfiltration.

low_findings.title: Bash script execution capability
low_findings.description: The skill includes a bash script (scripts/memory-query.sh) that executes shell commands. While these commands (find, grep, date) are standard system utilities used for file operations within the skill directory, bash scripts carry inherent risk if modified to include malicious commands. The script only operates within the memory directory structure.

content.user_title: Query AI project memories with SQL-style commands
content.value_statement: Track project history and decisions across AI sessions. Query episodic memories with SQL-like syntax for timeline analysis and knowledge consolidation.
actual_capabilities: Query episodic memories with SQL-style WHERE conditions
Filter events by date, type, tags, and custom fields
Generate timeline reports with table or JSON output
Access three-layer memory architecture (short-term, long-term, episodic)
Track project decisions and architectural choices
Consolidate knowledge from current sessions into long-term memory
limitations: Memory is stored locally within the project directory only
No cross-project memory sharing by default
No real-time sync with external systems
Query capabilities limited to predefined fields

use_cases.title: Track AI decisions
use_cases.description: Record and query architectural decisions made during AI development sessions

use_cases.title: Review project history
use_cases.description: Generate timeline reports showing project evolution and key milestones

use_cases.title: Consolidate insights
use_cases.description: Build long-term knowledge base from repeated project experiences

prompt_templates.title: Query today events
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me all memory events from today

prompt_templates.title: Find decisions
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all architecture decisions from the past week

prompt_templates.title: Timeline report
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me the project timeline for last month as a table

prompt_templates.title: Tag analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all events tagged with 'security' and export as JSON

output_examples.input: Show me all architecture decisions from the past week
output: decision-002       2025-11-13 15:22   Chosen PostgreSQL over MySQL for primary

best_practices: Use consistent tagging across all memory events
Record decisions with context including alternatives considered
Run weekly reviews using the timeline query feature
Consolidate short-term insights to long-term memory monthly
anti_patterns: Storing sensitive credentials or secrets in memory files
Leaving memory queries without proper date filters on large datasets
Skipping front matter metadata when creating new events
Mixing personal notes with project-related memories

faq.question: Which AI platforms support this skill?
faq.answer: Compatible with Claude, OpenAI Codex, and Claude Code CLI tools.

faq.question: What memory types are supported?
faq.answer: Three layers: short-term (current session), long-term (cross-project knowledge), episodic (project history).

faq.question: Can I query by custom fields?
faq.answer: Yes. Custom fields in YAML front matter are accessible via query when added to the meta dictionary.

faq.question: Is my data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: No. All memory data stays local within the .ai-runtime/memory directory in your project.

faq.question: Why are my queries returning empty results?
faq.answer: Check date format (YYYY-MM-DD), verify event files have valid YAML front matter, and ensure files are in the correct episodic subdirectory structure.

faq.question: How does this compare to vector databases?
faq.answer: This uses structured metadata querying rather than semantic similarity. Better for exact matches and timeline analysis, while vector databases excel at semantic search.
